additional_lessons.title: Blitz Concepts
additional_lessons.description: Learn different types of blitzes and when to use them

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a blitz?
options_json: Sending extra defenders to rush the QB
variant.explanation_richtext: A blitz sends more than the standard 4 pass rushers at the QB. Typically linebackers or defensive backs join the rush to create pressure.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is an A-gap blitz?
options_json: Blitz through the gaps next to the center
variant.explanation_richtext: An A-gap blitz sends defenders through the A gaps (spaces on either side of the center). It's a quick, inside blitz that's hard to block.

variant.prompt_richtext: Where is the B-gap?
variant.explanation_richtext: The B-gap is between the guard and tackle. B-gap blitzes are common and effective, targeting this natural seam in pass protection.

variant.prompt_richtext: Where is the C-gap?
variant.explanation_richtext: The C-gap is between the offensive tackle and tight end (or outside the tackle if no TE). C-gap blitzes come from the edge.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a zone blitz?
options_json: Blitz while playing zone coverage behind it
variant.explanation_richtext: A zone blitz sends 5+ rushers while the remaining defenders play zone coverage. Often a DL drops into coverage while a LB/DB blitzes.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a 'fire zone' blitz?
variant.explanation_richtext: Fire zone is a specific zone blitz package: 5 rushers with 6 defenders in coverage (3 deep, 3 underneath zones). It's very common in modern defenses.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a corner blitz?
options_json: Blitzing from the corner of the field
variant.explanation_richtext: A corner blitz sends the cornerback on a pass rush from the edge. It's surprising because corners usually cover receivers, not rush the QB.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a safety blitz?
options_json: Safety rushes the QB, usually up the middle
variant.explanation_richtext: A safety blitz sends a safety (usually from depth) to rush the QB. They often come up the middle with a running start, making them hard to block.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is the main risk of blitzing?
options_json: Fewer defenders in coverage, vulnerable to big plays
variant.explanation_richtext: When you blitz, you have fewer defenders in coverage. If the QB reads it and throws quickly, receivers can get behind the defense for big gains.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a delayed blitz?
options_json: Blitzer waits a moment before rushing
variant.explanation_richtext: A delayed blitz has the rusher wait a moment (showing coverage) before blitzing. This can confuse the offensive line and create open rush lanes.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is the primary goal of a blitz?
options_json: To create pressure and force a quick throw/sack
variant.explanation_richtext: Blitzing overwhelms the offensive line, forcing the QB to throw before they are ready or taking a sack.

variant.prompt_richtext: Why are A-gap blitzes difficult to block?
options_json: It's the shortest path to the QB
variant.explanation_richtext: The A-gap is the most direct line to the QB. Pressure up the middle prevents the QB from stepping up in the pocket.

variant.prompt_richtext: Why do defenses target the B-gap?
options_json: It's a natural seam in protection
variant.explanation_richtext: The B-gap (between guard and tackle) is a natural seam. Guards look inside, tackles look outside, leaving the B-gap vulnerable.

variant.prompt_richtext: Why is the Fire Zone blitz so common?
options_json: It's safe (3 deep defenders) while still bringing pressure
variant.explanation_richtext: Fire Zone is a 'safe' blitz because it keeps 3 defenders deep (Cover 3) to prevent big plays while overloading the protection.

variant.prompt_richtext: What makes a corner blitz effective?
options_json: Surprise and speed from the edge
variant.explanation_richtext: Offenses don't expect the corner to rush. Their speed off the edge can get to the QB before the tackle can react.

variant.prompt_richtext: Why are safety blitzes difficult to pick up?
options_json: They come from depth with a running start
variant.explanation_richtext: Safeties blitz from depth, timing their run to hit the line at full speed just as the ball is snapped.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is the strategic purpose of a delayed blitz?
options_json: To let the offensive line engage, then attack open lanes
variant.explanation_richtext: By waiting, the blitzer lets the O-line commit to other blocks. Then they attack the opening that appears.

additional_lessons.title: Defensive Line Play
additional_lessons.description: Learn defensive line techniques and responsibilities

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a defensive lineman's 'gap responsibility'?
options_json: The specific gap they must control
variant.explanation_richtext: Each defensive lineman is responsible for controlling a specific gap (A, B, or C). They must prevent runs through their gap and maintain gap integrity.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a defensive line 'stunt' or 'twist'?
options_json: Two linemen cross paths to confuse blockers
variant.explanation_richtext: A stunt (or twist) has two defensive linemen cross paths - one loops around the other. This creates confusion and can free up a rusher.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a 'T-E stunt'?
options_json: Tackle loops outside, end crashes inside
variant.explanation_richtext: A T-E (Tackle-End) stunt has the defensive tackle loop outside while the end crashes inside. It's designed to create one-on-one matchups for the tackle.

variant.prompt_richtext: What does 'penetration' mean for defensive linemen?
variant.explanation_richtext: Penetration means getting past the line of scrimmage into the backfield. It disrupts running plays and puts pressure on the QB.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is 'two-gap' technique?
options_json: Lineman controls two gaps on either side
variant.explanation_richtext: Two-gap technique has a lineman (usually nose tackle) control both gaps on either side of them. They read the play and fill whichever gap the run goes to.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is 'one-gap' technique?
variant.explanation_richtext: One-gap technique has each lineman attack a specific gap. It's more aggressive and penetrating than two-gap, but requires more discipline.

variant.prompt_richtext: What does 'contain' mean for defensive ends?
options_json: Keep the play inside, don't let it bounce outside
variant.explanation_richtext: Contain responsibility means the defensive end must keep the play from bouncing outside. They 'set the edge' and force runs back inside to the pursuit.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a 'bull rush'?
options_json: Power rush straight through the blocker
variant.explanation_richtext: A bull rush is a power move where the rusher drives straight through the blocker using strength and leverage. It's the most basic pass rush move.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a 'speed rush'?
options_json: Using speed to run around the blocker
variant.explanation_richtext: A speed rush uses quickness and agility to run around the edge of the blocker. It's effective for fast defensive ends against slower tackles.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a 'swim move'?
options_json: Rusher swims their arm over the blocker's shoulder
variant.explanation_richtext: The swim move has the rusher use their arm in a swimming motion to go over the blocker's shoulder and get past them.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is the goal of a defensive line stunt?
options_json: To confuse blocking assignments and free a rusher
variant.explanation_richtext: Stunts force offensive linemen to pass off defenders. If they miscommunicate or are too slow, a defender comes free.

variant.prompt_richtext: What does a T-E stunt try to achieve?
options_json: Isolate the tackle on the looping defensive tackle
variant.explanation_richtext: The end crashing inside occupies the guard, leaving the offensive tackle to deal with the looping defensive tackle in space.

variant.prompt_richtext: Why is defensive line penetration disruptive?
options_json: It forces the RB to change path or the QB to move
variant.explanation_richtext: Penetration destroys the timing of plays. A RB has to cut back early, or a QB can't step into a throw.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is the primary responsibility in two-gap technique?
options_json: Read the blocker and shed them to the ball side
variant.explanation_richtext: The defender must control the blocker first, read where the ball is going, and then shed the block to fill the correct gap.

variant.prompt_richtext: How does one-gap technique differ from two-gap?
options_json: One-gap is aggressive/penetrating; Two-gap is reading/reacting
variant.explanation_richtext: One-gap is about shooting a gap and getting upfield fast. Two-gap is about controlling a blocker and waiting to see the play develop.

variant.prompt_richtext: Why is 'containing' the edge critical?
options_json: To force the ball carrier back inside to help
variant.explanation_richtext: If the edge is lost, the runner has open field to the sideline. Contain forces them back into the middle where the other defenders are.

variant.prompt_richtext: When is a speed rush most effective?
options_json: Against a slow or heavy-footed tackle
variant.explanation_richtext: If the offensive tackle has slow feet, they can't kick slide fast enough to stop a speed rusher from turning the corner.

additional_lessons.title: Linebacker Responsibilities
additional_lessons.description: Learn what linebackers do in different situations

variant.prompt_richtext: What is the middle linebacker's primary role?
options_json: Stop inside runs and cover the middle
variant.explanation_richtext: The middle linebacker (MLB) is the defensive quarterback. They stop inside runs, cover tight ends and running backs, and make defensive calls.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a linebacker's 'run fit'?
options_json: Their assigned gap to fill on running plays
How well they fit in their uniform
variant.explanation_richtext: Run fit is the specific gap a linebacker is responsible for filling on run plays. Each defender has a gap to ensure all running lanes are covered.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a 'scrape' by a linebacker?
options_json: Flowing laterally behind the line to fill a gap
variant.explanation_richtext: Scraping is when a linebacker flows laterally (parallel to the line) to fill a gap. It's used against outside runs and when linemen pull.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is the 'hook zone' in coverage?
variant.explanation_richtext: The hook zone (or hook/curl zone) is the intermediate middle area 10-15 yards deep. Linebackers typically drop here to defend curl and hook routes.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a 'curl/flat' defender?
options_json: Defender reads #2 receiver to determine coverage
variant.explanation_richtext: A curl/flat defender (usually a LB) reads the #2 receiver. If #2 goes vertical, they cover the flat. If #2 stays short, they cover the curl zone.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is the 'Mike' linebacker?
options_json: The middle linebacker or the one the offense identifies
variant.explanation_richtext: The 'Mike' is typically the middle linebacker, but the offense identifies who they consider the Mike for protection purposes. It's a key pre-snap read.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is the 'Sam' linebacker?
variant.explanation_richtext: The Sam linebacker is the strong-side outside linebacker (usually to the tight end side). They often have to cover tight ends and set the edge on runs.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is the 'Will' linebacker?
variant.explanation_richtext: The Will linebacker is the weak-side outside linebacker (away from the tight end). They're often the fastest LB and good in coverage.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a 'spy' assignment for a linebacker?
options_json: Shadow the QB to prevent scrambles
variant.explanation_richtext: A spy assignment has a linebacker (or sometimes a safety) shadow the QB to prevent scrambles. They don't rush but stay ready to tackle if the QB runs.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a 'stack' alignment for linebackers?
options_json: LB lines up directly behind a defensive lineman
variant.explanation_richtext: Stack alignment has the linebacker line up directly behind a defensive lineman.

variant.prompt_richtext: Why is the MLB known as the 'defensive quarterback'?
options_json: They receive the play call and align the defense
variant.explanation_richtext: Like the QB on offense, the MLB communicates the play call, makes adjustments, and ensures everyone is in position.

variant.prompt_richtext: Why is maintaining run fits important?
options_json: To prevent gaps in the defensive front
variant.explanation_richtext: If one player abandons their gap (fit), it creates a hole in the defense that a running back can exploit for a big gain.

variant.prompt_richtext: When should a linebacker 'scrape'?
options_json: When the play flows outside or a lineman pulls
variant.explanation_richtext: Scraping allows the LB to get over the top of traffic to meet the ball carrier on the outside.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is the advantage of stacking linebackers?
options_json: It protects the LB from blockers
variant.explanation_richtext: The lineman in front occupies the blocker, keeping the linebacker 'clean' (unblocked) to flow to the ball and make the tackle.

additional_lessons.title: Secondary Coverage
additional_lessons.description: Learn defensive back techniques and responsibilities

variant.prompt_richtext: What is press coverage?
options_json: DB lines up close and jams receiver at the line
variant.explanation_richtext: Press coverage has the defensive back line up within 5 yards and physically jam the receiver at the line to disrupt their route. It's aggressive man coverage.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is off coverage?
options_json: DB gives 5-10 yard cushion to the receiver
variant.explanation_richtext: Off coverage has the DB give a cushion (5-10 yards) to the receiver. This prevents getting beat deep but allows short completions underneath.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is 'bail' technique?
options_json: DB turns and runs with receiver at the snap
DB gives up on the play
variant.explanation_richtext: Bail technique has the DB turn and run with the receiver at the snap. It's used in zone coverage to get depth quickly and protect against deep routes.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a backpedal?
options_json: DB runs backward to maintain vision on receiver
variant.explanation_richtext: Backpedaling is running backward while maintaining vision on the receiver and QB. It allows the DB to react to routes while keeping depth.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is 'leverage' in DB coverage?
options_json: DB's position relative to receiver and sideline
variant.explanation_richtext: Leverage is the DB's position relative to the receiver and sideline. Inside leverage means positioned toward the middle; outside leverage toward the sideline.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is 'trail' technique in man coverage?
options_json: DB runs behind receiver, playing the ball
variant.explanation_richtext: Trail technique has the DB run behind the receiver in man coverage, focusing on the ball and receiver's hands. It's used when you have inside help.

variant.prompt_richtext: What does 'high-low' mean in coverage?
options_json: Two defenders cover one receiver at different depths
variant.explanation_richtext: High-low coverage has two defenders bracket one receiver - one underneath (low) and one deep (high). It's used to take away a team's best receiver.

variant.prompt_richtext: In zone coverage, what should a DB's 'eyes' be on?
variant.explanation_richtext: In zone coverage, DBs should have their eyes on the QB to read where the pass is going, while using peripheral vision to track receivers in their zone.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a 'break point' in coverage?
options_json: When the receiver makes their cut
variant.explanation_richtext: The break point is when the receiver makes their cut or breaks on their route. DBs must recognize this and drive on the ball to make a play.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is 'man match' coverage?
options_json: Hybrid of man and zone based on route patterns
variant.explanation_richtext: Man match (or pattern match) coverage starts as zone but has defenders match receivers man-to-man based on their routes.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is the strategic goal of press coverage?
options_json: To disrupt timing and reroute receivers
variant.explanation_richtext: By jamming the receiver, the DB ruins the timing of the route, throwing off the QB's rhythm.

variant.prompt_richtext: Why would a corner play off coverage?
options_json: To prevent deep passes and keep everything in front
variant.explanation_richtext: Off coverage gives the DB a head start to react to deep routes, ensuring they don't get beaten over the top.

variant.prompt_richtext: When is bail technique typically used?
variant.explanation_richtext: Bail technique allows a corner to appear to be in press/shallow coverage but quickly retreat to a deep zone at the snap.

variant.prompt_richtext: Why is backpedaling essential for DBs?
options_json: To keep eyes on the QB/receiver while retreating
variant.explanation_richtext: You can't see the play if you turn your back. Backpedaling lets you retreat while reading the play.

variant.prompt_richtext: When is trail technique most effective?
options_json: When you have safety help over the top
variant.explanation_richtext: If you have deep help, you can aggressively undercut the route (trail) to defend short/intermediate throws without fear of getting beat deep.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is the purpose of high-low coverage?
options_json: To double team a key receiver
variant.explanation_richtext: It forces the QB to throw into a tight window between two defenders, effectively neutralizing a star receiver.

variant.prompt_richtext: Why do zone defenders keep their eyes on the QB?
options_json: To anticipate where the ball will be thrown
variant.explanation_richtext: The QB's eyes often give away the target. Reading the QB allows defenders to break on the ball faster.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is the main advantage of man-match coverage?
options_json: Combines tight man coverage with zone safety
variant.explanation_richtext: It prevents defenders from covering empty grass (zone) while avoiding the mismatches of pure man coverage.

additional_lessons.title: Tackling Fundamentals
additional_lessons.description: Learn proper tackling techniques and pursuit angles

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a 'form tackle'?
options_json: Head up, wrap arms, drive through the ball carrier
variant.explanation_richtext: A form tackle uses proper technique: head up, eyes on target, wrap arms around the ball carrier, and drive through. It's the safest and most effective tackling method.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a pursuit angle?
options_json: Path defender takes to intercept the ball carrier
variant.explanation_richtext: Pursuit angle is the path a defender takes to intercept the ball carrier.

variant.prompt_richtext: What does 'leverage' mean in tackling?
options_json: Getting lower than the ball carrier
variant.explanation_richtext: Leverage in tackling means getting your pad level lower than the ball carrier's. The lower player usually wins the collision and makes the tackle.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is gang tackling?
options_json: Multiple defenders tackling the ball carrier together
variant.explanation_richtext: Gang tackling is when multiple defenders swarm to the ball carrier and tackle together. It prevents yards after contact and can cause fumbles.

variant.prompt_richtext: Why is 'wrapping up' important in tackling?
options_json: Secures the tackle and prevents the runner from escaping
variant.explanation_richtext: Wrapping up means securing your arms around the ball carrier. Without wrapping, runners can break tackles and gain extra yards.

variant.prompt_richtext: What makes open field tackles difficult?
options_json: Ball carrier has space to make moves
variant.explanation_richtext: Open field tackles are one-on-one in space. The ball carrier can use speed and moves to avoid the tackle. Defenders must break down and maintain leverage.

variant.prompt_richtext: What does 'breaking down' mean in tackling?
options_json: Slowing down, getting in athletic stance, preparing to tackle
variant.explanation_richtext: Breaking down means slowing from a sprint to a controlled position - feet chopping, knees bent, ready to react. It prevents overrunning the ball carrier.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is 'stripping the ball'?
options_json: Punching the ball out while tackling
variant.explanation_richtext: Stripping the ball means punching or raking at the ball while tackling to cause a fumble. The first defender wraps up while the second strips.

variant.prompt_richtext: What does 'fitting up' mean in run defense?
variant.explanation_richtext: Fitting up means each defender fills their assigned gap with proper leverage. When all 11 defenders fit correctly, there are no running lanes.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a shoulder tackle?
options_json: Leading with shoulder pad into ball carrier
variant.explanation_richtext: A shoulder tackle drives the shoulder pad into the ball carrier while wrapping up. It's powerful but must be done with head up to avoid injury.
